speaker: Both
text_entry: SCENE II. Kimbolton.

speaker: Both
text_entry: Enter KATHARINE, Dowager, sick; led between GRIFFITH, her gentleman usher, and PATIENCE, her woman

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: How does your grace?

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: O Griffith, sick to death!

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: My legs, like loaden branches, bow to the earth,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Willing to leave their burthen. Reach a chair:

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: So; now, methinks, I feel a little ease.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Didst thou not tell me, Griffith, as thou led'st me,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: That the great child of honour, Cardinal Wolsey, Was dead?

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Yes, madam; but I think your grace,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Out of the pain you suffer'd, gave no ear to't.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Prithee, good Griffith, tell me how he died:

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: If well, he stepp'd before me, happily

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: For my example.

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Well, the voice goes, madam:

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: For after the stout Earl Northumberland

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Arrested him at York, and brought him forward,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: As a man sorely tainted, to his answer,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: He fell sick suddenly, and grew so ill

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: He could not sit his mule.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Alas, poor man!

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: At last, with easy roads, he came to Leicester,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Lodged in the abbey; where the reverend abbot,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: With all his covent, honourably received him;

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: To whom he gave these words, 'O, father abbot,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: An old man, broken with the storms of state,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Is come to lay his weary bones among ye;

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Give him a little earth for charity!'

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: So went to bed; where eagerly his sickness

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Pursued him still: and, three nights after this,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: About the hour of eight, which he himself

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Foretold should be his last, full of repentance,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Continual meditations, tears, and sorrows,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: He gave his honours to the world again,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: His blessed part to heaven, and slept in peace.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: So may he rest; his faults lie gently on him!

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Yet thus far, Griffith, give me leave to speak him,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: And yet with charity. He was a man

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Of an unbounded stomach, ever ranking

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Himself with princes; one that, by suggestion,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Tied all the kingdom: simony was fair-play;

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: His own opinion was his law: i' the presence

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: He would say untruths; and be ever double

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Both in his words and meaning: he was never,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: But where he meant to ruin, pitiful:

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: His promises were, as he then was, mighty;

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: But his performance, as he is now, nothing:

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Of his own body he was ill, and gave

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: The clergy in example.

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Noble madam,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Men's evil manners live in brass; their virtues

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: We write in water. May it please your highness

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: To hear me speak his good now?

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Yes, good Griffith;

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: I were malicious else.

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: This cardinal,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Though from an humble stock, undoubtedly

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Was fashion'd to much honour from his cradle.

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: He was a scholar, and a ripe and good one;

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Exceeding wise, fair-spoken, and persuading:

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Lofty and sour to them that loved him not;

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: But to those men that sought him sweet as summer.

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: And though he were unsatisfied in getting,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Which was a sin, yet in bestowing, madam,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: He was most princely: ever witness for him

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Those twins Of learning that he raised in you,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Ipswich and Oxford! one of which fell with him,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Unwilling to outlive the good that did it;

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: The other, though unfinish'd, yet so famous,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: So excellent in art, and still so rising,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: That Christendom shall ever speak his virtue.

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: His overthrow heap'd happiness upon him;

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: For then, and not till then, he felt himself,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: And found the blessedness of being little:

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: And, to add greater honours to his age

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Than man could give him, he died fearing God.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: After my death I wish no other herald,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: No other speaker of my living actions,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: To keep mine honour from corruption,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: But such an honest chronicler as Griffith.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Whom I most hated living, thou hast made me,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: With thy religious truth and modesty,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Now in his ashes honour: peace be with him!

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Patience, be near me still; and set me lower:

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: I have not long to trouble thee. Good Griffith,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Cause the musicians play me that sad note

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: I named my knell, whilst I sit meditating

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: On that celestial harmony I go to.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Sad and solemn music

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: She is asleep: good wench, let's sit down quiet,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: For fear we wake her: softly, gentle Patience.

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: The vision. Enter, solemnly tripping one after  another, six personages, clad in white robes,  wearing on their heads garlands of bays, and golden  vizards on their faces; branches of bays or palm in  their hands. They first congee unto her, then  dance; and, at certain changes, the first two hold  a spare garland over her head; at which the other  four make reverent curtsies; then the two that held  the garland deliver the same to the other next two,  who observe the same order in their changes, and  holding the garland over her head: which done,  they deliver the same garland to the last two, who  likewise observe the same order: at which, as it  were by inspiration, she makes in her sleep signs  of rejoicing, and holdeth up her hands to heaven:  and so in their dancing vanish, carrying the garland with them. The music continues

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Spirits of peace, where are ye? are ye all gone,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: And leave me here in wretchedness behind ye?

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Madam, we are here.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: It is not you I call for:

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Saw ye none enter since I slept?

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: None, madam.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: No? Saw you not, even now, a blessed troop

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Invite me to a banquet; whose bright faces

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Cast thousand beams upon me, like the sun?

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: They promised me eternal happiness;

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: And brought me garlands, Griffith, which I feel

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: I am not worthy yet to wear: I shall, assuredly.

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: I am most joyful, madam, such good dreams

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Possess your fancy.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Bid the music leave,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: They are harsh and heavy to me.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Music ceases

speaker: PATIENCE
text_entry: Do you note

speaker: PATIENCE
text_entry: How much her grace is alter'd on the sudden?

speaker: PATIENCE
text_entry: How long her face is drawn? how pale she looks,

speaker: PATIENCE
text_entry: And of an earthy cold? Mark her eyes!

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: She is going, wench: pray, pray.

speaker: PATIENCE
text_entry: Heaven comfort her!

speaker: PATIENCE
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: An't like your grace,--

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: You are a saucy fellow:

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Deserve we no more reverence?

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: You are to blame,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: Knowing she will not lose her wonted greatness,

speaker: GRIFFITH
text_entry: To use so rude behavior; go to, kneel.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: I humbly do entreat your highness' pardon;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: My haste made me unmannerly. There is staying

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: A gentleman, sent from the king, to see you.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Admit him entrance, Griffith: but this fellow

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Let me ne'er see again.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Exeunt GRIFFITH and Messenger

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Re-enter GRIFFITH, with CAPUCIUS

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: If my sight fail not,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: You should be lord ambassador from the emperor,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: My royal nephew, and your name Capucius.

speaker: CAPUCIUS
text_entry: Madam, the same; your servant.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: O, my lord,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: The times and titles now are alter'd strangely

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: With me since first you knew me. But, I pray you,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: What is your pleasure with me?

speaker: CAPUCIUS
text_entry: Noble lady,

speaker: CAPUCIUS
text_entry: First mine own service to your grace; the next,

speaker: CAPUCIUS
text_entry: The king's request that I would visit you;

speaker: CAPUCIUS
text_entry: Who grieves much for your weakness, and by me

speaker: CAPUCIUS
text_entry: Sends you his princely commendations,

speaker: CAPUCIUS
text_entry: And heartily entreats you take good comfort.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: O my good lord, that comfort comes too late;

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: 'Tis like a pardon after execution:

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: That gentle physic, given in time, had cured me;

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: But now I am past an comforts here, but prayers.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: How does his highness?

speaker: CAPUCIUS
text_entry: Madam, in good health.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: So may he ever do! and ever flourish,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: When I shal l dwell with worms, and my poor name

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Banish'd the kingdom! Patience, is that letter,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: I caused you write, yet sent away?

speaker: PATIENCE
text_entry: No, madam.

speaker: PATIENCE
text_entry: Giving it to KATHARINE

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Sir, I most humbly pray you to deliver

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: This to my lord the king.

speaker: CAPUCIUS
text_entry: Most willing, madam.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: In which I have commended to his goodness

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: The model of our chaste loves, his young daughter;

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: The dews of heaven fall thick in blessings on her!

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Beseeching him to give her virtuous breeding--

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: She is young, and of a noble modest nature,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: I hope she will deserve well,--and a little

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: To love her for her mother's sake, that loved him,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Heaven knows how dearly. My next poor petition

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Is, that his noble grace would have some pity

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Upon my wretched women, that so long

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Have follow'd both my fortunes faithfully:

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Of which there is not one, I dare avow,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: And now I should not lie, but will deserve

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: For virtue and true beauty of the soul,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: For honesty and decent carriage,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: A right good husband, let him be a noble

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: And, sure, those men are happy that shall have 'em.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: The last is, for my men; they are the poorest,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: But poverty could never draw 'em from me;

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: That they may have their wages duly paid 'em,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: And something over to remember me by:

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: If heaven had pleased to have given me longer life

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: And able means, we had not parted thus.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: These are the whole contents: and, good my lord,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: By that you love the dearest in this world,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: As you wish Christian peace to souls departed,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Stand these poor people's friend, and urge the king

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: To do me this last right.

speaker: CAPUCIUS
text_entry: By heaven, I will,

speaker: CAPUCIUS
text_entry: Or let me lose the fashion of a man!

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: I thank you, honest lord. Remember me

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: In all humility unto his highness:

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Say his long trouble now is passing

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Out of this world; tell him, in death I bless'd him,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: For so I will. Mine eyes grow dim. Farewell,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: My lord. Griffith, farewell. Nay, Patience,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: You must not leave me yet: I must to bed;

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Call in more women. When I am dead, good wench,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Let me be used with honour: strew me over

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: With maiden flowers, that all the world may know

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: I was a chaste wife to my grave: embalm me,

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Then lay me forth: although unqueen'd, yet like

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: A queen, and daughter to a king, inter me.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: I can no more.

speaker: KATHARINE
text_entry: Exeunt, leading KATHARINE
